column1: Reviewer 1;Author;1;1;0;1) It is not indicated in the introduction whether any alternative to thin films of yttrium iron garnet is currently being considered for use as magneto-optical resonators.

Reviewer 1;Author;1;2;0;2) How will the temperature dependence of the Faraday rotation hysteresis loops of Dy:CeYIG thin films change when moving to another wavelength range? Is there any dependence on the wavelength?
Reviewer 1;Author;1;3;0;3) How can one explain the increase in the value of the Faraday rotation angle in the range of 30-40 degrees for Dy:CeYIG (Fig. 3f)

column1: Reviewer 2;Author;1;4;0;4) Figures 2 (c) and (d). While the Faraday rotation angle appears to decrease more or less linearly with temperature in the Ce:YIG film (as far as can be inferred from the non-linear horizontal scale)
column2: the decrease is not taking place at the same rate in the Dy:Ce:YIG film. What causes this different behavior?

column1: Reviewer 2;Author;1;5;0;5) Figures 3 (a) and (b): It could be good to use the same horizontal scale for a clearer comparison.
Author;Reviewer 1;2;1;1;"Thanks for the commerts. To the best of our knowledge
column2: rare earth doped yttrium iron garnet is still the main material used for magneto-optical devices. They include bismuth doped YIG
column4: terbium doped YIG and cerium doped YIG. Other materials such as Wely semimatels are still under theoretical study[1]. We have added comments to these materials in the manuscript.
rare earth doped yttrium iron garnet (RIG) is the most widely used magneto-optical material in integrated MO devices.”"

column1: Author;Reviewer 1;2;2;2;Thanks for the commerts. Absoultly there is also temperature dependence of the Faraday rotation when shift to other wavelengths. However
column2: the transparency window of this material is in the 1550 nm wavelength range. When moving to shorter wavelengths
column3: the absorption of this material increases sharply
column4: making them less practical for photonic device applications.

column1: Author;Reviewer 1;2;3;3;"Thanks for the commerts. The saturation magnetization of rare-earth doped YIG affects the Faraday rotation angle. Sayetat et al. and Ostorero et al. previously reported that the compensation temperature of DyIG is Tcomp = 225 K [2
column3: which could decrease the Faraday rotation angle of Dy:CeIG in this work at the temperature below 300 K. Therefore
column4: a higher Faraday rotation may be related to the increase of the saturation magnetization of this material in this temperature range.

column3: added “The increase of the Faraday rotation below 40 ℃ is possibly due to the increase of the magnetization of this material at this temperature range
